headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Alabama Boat Dock Brawl; Starliner Ready for NASA By Next March; Oakland Residents Sound the Alarm over Crime. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: LAUREN SPLVEY, WITNESS
utterances.sentences: You know, just doing his job. And for some reason they didn't like it. They didn't want to move the boat. And he decided to get physical with him.

utterances.speaker: YOUNG
utterances.sentences: You can see in the video, the black employee on the dock arguing with one of the men from the pontoon boat. And then another shirtless white man charging at the employee and hitting him in the face. Soon after that you can see several others join in on the attack of the dock employee.In some of the video, which has gone viral, with millions of views, people on the boat can be heard yelling for someone to go help the employee. Then at one point you can see a young man, who has jumped off the boat, swimming ashore to help the man who was being attacked.

utterances.speaker: SPLVEY
utterances.sentences: The boat got closer. The guys and the crew members and everybody got off and that's when it happened. That's the reason why I -- when they got off the boat they came right to that smaller boat.

utterances.speaker: YOUNG
utterances.sentences: And that's when more fighting ensues, turning into an all-out brawl that included several people getting hit over the head with a folding chair. Soon after, officers started trying to take control, handcuffing people in the fight.

utterances.speaker: SPLVEY
utterances.sentences: You know, they were the antagonist of the whole situation. Arrest them because unfortunately when things happen, people of color are the first to put -- be put in handcuffs.

utterances.speaker: YOUNG
utterances.sentences: Many questions remain about the melee that appeared to be very much split across racial lines.

utterances.speaker: REED
utterances.sentences: We are fully engaged and we are doing all of our due diligence to find out exactly what took place. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: YOUNG
utterances.sentences: And, Victor, I don't know if we can underscore enough the fact of how social media has really taken this to the next level when it comes to talking about this story. People really want answers about how this escalated so quickly. Why blows were thrown so many times. But they do know that a lot of people reacted to that worker in need, the fact that he was being hit and jumped before everyone else jumped in to try to solve this.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: YOUNG
utterances.sentences: So, it will be interesting to see what happens today at that news conference.

utterances.speaker: VICTOR BLACKWELL, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, the man was just doing his job and asking them, as he should have, to move the boat. And they attacked him.Ryan Young, thank you for that.

utterances.speaker: YOUNG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, this morning, a driver in central Pennsylvania could face some serious charges after police say he intentionally crashed his car into the second floor of a home. You can see the car wedged into the side of the home. This was on Sunday. Officials say the driver was speeding, went off road into a field, then went airborne, crashing into that house. The suspect is 20 years old, was taken to the hospital. We hope they're doing OK. Local reports say the three people in the home at the time are not hurt, thank goodness. Crews were able to remove the car and put a tarp over the hole it left behind.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: That's unreal.Well, is air pollution making infectious diseases more dangerous? What a new study is revealing this morning.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, this morning, a top official of the Federal Reserve is warning multiple rate hikes could still be needed to get inflation back to healthy, normal 2 percent levels. Fed Governor Michelle Bowman said they have made progress in lowering inflation over the past two years. Still, though, they have a long way to go. Last month the fed raised its interest rates by quarter point, lifting rates to the highest level in 22 years. This is the 11th increase since March of 2022. It came a month after the central bank paused rates. But where do they go now?CNN business correspondent Rahel Solomon is with us. Good morning.

utterances.speaker: RAHEL SOLOMON, CNN BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Good morning. Good to be with you, guy.So, that is the big debate, where do they go now, and how -- we all thought -- many people thought that we were sort of at the end of the rate hiking cycle. Now there's a question of how close we are. So, the issue is that although we have come a long way, remember when Consumer Price Index was at 9 percent last year in the June - in June. We're closer to 3 percent. But when you look at core inflation, stripping away categories like food and energy, it is still much higher than the Fed would like. And so there was a question now of, even though we have come so far, do they still do more? As you said, Governor Bowman said that more rate hikes may be necessary. She has been saying that. But I think it raised some eyebrows when she made these comments yesterday because we had hoped that we were closer to the end, and we wouldn't have to necessarily see more rate hikes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK, we'll see what's to come. Thank you, Rahel.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Rahel.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: NASA's plans for an additional vehicle to take astronauts to the International Space Station will have to wait, at least until 2024. That's because Boeing says Starliner will not be ready to launch until next March at the earliest. Currently NASA is using SpaceX to ferry the crew.CNN's Kristin Fisher joins us from -- near the Kennedy Space Center. Why the delays?

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: All right, we'll look forward to it. Thank you, Kristin.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, always exciting.The NAACP of Oakland, California, has called for a state of emergency over rampant crime. Next you're going to hear from residents who say they're fed up and they're moving out. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KRISTIN COOK, MOVING OUT OF OAKLAND
utterances.sentences: The fact that I am being pushed out because I emotionally can't take it anymore is horrible.(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: KRISTIN COOK, MOVING OUT OF OAKLAND
utterances.sentences: I love Oakland. It's very hard for me and my son, especially my son.KYUNG LAH, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice over):  So Kristin Cook is leaving Oakland, California.

utterances.speaker: COOK
utterances.sentences: Be careful.

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: After living here her entire life.

utterances.speaker: COOK
utterances.sentences: I can't take it anymore. I got to the point I was too scared to leave my house.

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: Cook blames brazen assaults and robberies in broad daylight, break-ins and home invasions across the city as Oakland sees a surge in reported violent crimes this year compared to last. While homicides are down, robberies, burglaries and rape are all up by double digit percentages. Everyone we talked to says it doesn't matter your race, your income, everyone seems to be a target, including carjackings, like this one.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No. Ah!

utterances.speaker: COOK
utterances.sentences: Now they're carjacking people at stop signs. And my son is about to start driving. The fact that I am being pushed out because I emotionally can't take it anymore is horrible.

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: But Toni Bird is staying. She lives with a locked front gate and five security cameras. Bird says Oakland police recommended steel braces for residential doors, and air horns.

utterances.speaker: TONI BIRD, OAKLAND RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: The idea is if you set it off, your neighbor would hear it, set theirs off, and more people are alert that there's danger.

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: Her neighbor across the street, 60-year-old retiree Dave Schneider, was shot to death in June trimming his front tree during the day. He died as Bird and other neighbors tried to save him.

utterances.speaker: BIRD
utterances.sentences: I'm not looking for the perfect, safe place. I'm looking for a place where the elderly, women with children, aren't targeted. I think we can all agree that that needs to change. And so I feel like it will change. And that's why I'm staying.

utterances.speaker: TROY WELCH, OWNER, LAUREL ACE HARDWARE
utterances.sentences: Find everything you're looking for OK?

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: But saying open gets tougher every day for Troy Welch, own of Laurel Ace Hardware.

utterances.speaker: WELCH
utterances.sentences: There's about six of them that comes in.

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: Welch's store was robbed just hours before we met him. WELCHBut you'll see they went in, they tried to take a sledge hammer to it. Tried to lift it. And he's going to figure out they ain't - they aren't getting into that safe.

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: Welch says he loses 10 percent of his merchandise to theft. So common this year he leaves his registers empty and open, tired of replacing them.

utterances.speaker: WELCH
utterances.sentences: It's more brazen. Sometimes more violent I think than what it used to be.LAH (on camera): How long does it take for police to arrive?

utterances.speaker: WELCH
utterances.sentences: Forty-five minutes.

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: Forty-five minutes. Is that typical?

utterances.speaker: WELCH
utterances.sentences: That's probably fast.LAH (voice over): Frustration has spilled over in community meetings. Anger often directed at leadership, like the newly-elected district attorney, who has been on the job just seven months.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's unreal!

utterances.speaker: DARREN WHITE, OAKLAND NAACP
utterances.sentences: I'm a black man, born and raised in Oakland. When I walk out of the house every day, I want to be safe. So, if that calls for some -- whoever commits the crime to be prosecuted, so be it. But we want it to be fair and just.

utterances.speaker: LAH
utterances.sentences: Darren White is with the NAACP Oakland branch, which penned an open letter to their city blaming failed leadership, the defund the police movement and anti-police rhetoric for creating a heyday for Oakland criminals.

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: We're not trying to say, you know, mass incarceration and arrest everyone. We want the people that are out here committing these violent crimes arrested and charged.LAH (on camera): Do we need more cops on the street?

utterances.speaker: WHITE
utterances.sentences: Yes, we do need more. Every community needs police.LAH (voice over): Franked by partners in the city, Oakland's interim police chief, Darren Allison, says Oakland is taking a comprehensive approach to fighting crime. LAH (on camera): And they all say that the crime feels different now. Why is that?

utterances.speaker: INTERIM POLICE CHIEF DARREN ALLISON, OAKLAND, CALIFORNIA
utterances.sentences: So, I think because it is pervasive, not just localized, or even may have historically seen maybe gang group violence, I think that feeling has become that it's everywhere.LAH (voice over): From cops to crime prevention, funded for 712 officers, Allison says he has 715 on staff.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: So, what you're seeing is changes in bail, changes in sentencing.LAH (on camera): Are you saying you need tougher punishment on the back end?

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: It's everything. It's not just enforcement and punishment. I think accountability comes in many forms.LAH (voice over): Kyung Lah, CNN, Los Angeles. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: John Avlon, Jessica Washington are back with us.It more than feels different. The numbers show that in certain categories it's up double digits. The question is the balance here of enforcing the law, getting people who need to be off the street off the street, but also not going too far in the other direction.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: That's not too much to ask. And you see these stats, you got to take action because it's unleashing massive forces. You can't effectively have situations where, for example, you know, mass theft, going into stores and, you know, grabbing things under $1,000 is effectively decriminalized.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But explain why that matters.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, John's pointing to the fact that the law reads now -- I don't know if it's state, if it's just California, or if it's national, but that if - if it's under 1,000 -- what did you say?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Under $1,000.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Under $1,000.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: I believe it's California or it's -- it's per store - HARLOW

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Because it's worth the hassle to prosecution.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Under $1,000. If you steal $999 of stuff it's a misdemeanor.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It's not - and - and so a lot of people are pointing to things like that and saying, this is leading to it just continuing.JESSICA WASHINGTON, SENIOR REPORTER, "THE ROOT": Yes. And I think that we can look at specific laws and say, OK, maybe this one needs to change. But I think the overwhelming message is, what happened here was the defund movement. And what happened was getting police off the street. I think that's what we saw in the NAACP letter. And the thing is, that's not what happened. Oakland has continuously increased their police budget. And so - and you can also - you can quibble with, it didn't match up with inflation. There's different arguments about whether or not they've increased it enough. But they increased it by 18 percent from 2019 to 2022. They increased it again this year. So, this isn't an issue of, we are taking police off the street. There were no layoffs in the police department in this year's budget. And you know, I think the argument is they actually did decrease community violence intervention program funding in this year's budget. So, are there things that we could be doing that we are not doing? We are funding the police in Oakland and yet there is still crime. So, are there other methods that aren't this trade-off that we could be investing in.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Look, I think it's a 2 percent increase this calendar year. But to you point, I think it's - it's about the larger movement that's associated with that disastrous term defund the police. It's about cops backing off. It's about feeling the prosecutions aren't going forward. That, you know, that there is this revolving door issue approach to crime and punishment, which you heard people in the piece complain about, including the police officers.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We can look at - you can look at places like Camden, New Jersey, that have completely restructured, redone their police force. I was reporting there. I mean this was years ago.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But it was incredibly successful, saying this isn't working, and a complete overhaul.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: And, look, this is an area that should be open to innovation, but you need to separate intentions from results. And if public safety is dropping down, if people are feeling unsafe, not as a matter of perception but hard reality, as you heard that woman crying in the street because she has to leave Oakland because people are getting shot, you know, out in broad daylight they're getting their cars stolen, that demands reaction or you are breeding reactionary forces politically. This is just about actually public safety. This is about protecting people. And it shouldn't be politicized.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: All right, John -

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't -

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Go ahead, quickly.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Oh, sorry, I was just going to say that, you know, it is true that this is about action, but I would think that the folks who are saying we have tried policing over and over again and our community still feels unsafe. We've increased the budget and are saying, what about these other methods that we haven't tried, we haven't invested in. Those are not people who don't care about safety.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: Those are people that care deeply about their community. And I think sometimes we pinpoint those as individuals who do not care about keeping the streets that. And that's just not born out.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: All right, Jessica, John, thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. And great reporting by Kyung. Our thanks to her.Meantime, new CNN reporting shows House Republicans really eyeing seriously an impeachment inquiry against President Joe Biden in the fall.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Major League Baseball is handing down the punishments for benches clearing brawls on Thursday - or Saturday rather. The White Sox/Guardians game. Chicago's Tim Anderson received a six-game suspension and a fine for trading punches with Cleveland third baseman Jose Ramirez. He received a three-game ban and a fine. Now, both players are appealing and will still be allowed to play until a final decision is made.In total, MLB punished eight people Monday, including both managers who each received a one game suspension and a fine. The White Sox and Guardians do not play each other again this season. CNN THIS MORNING continues right now.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Good morning, everyone. So glad you're with us. Top of the hour. Victor Blackwell beside my side.Good morning. BLACKWELL: Day two of five. Good to be here.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Day two of five. That's all I get, five days?

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: You get five later this month.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Then you're going to Beyonce.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm going to Beyonce.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I don't blame you.

utterances.speaker: BLACKWELL
utterances.sentences: Then I'll be back.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Let's get started with "5 Things" to know for this Tuesday, August 8th.New this morning, the East Coast cleaning up after deadly storms. Trees are down, roads are blocked. Hundreds of thousands of people without power this morning. Already more than 300 flights cancelled.
